2012 RMP UPDATE DUE TO ADDING 2ND ANHYDROUS AMMONIA SYSTEM TO A NEW ELECTRIC GENERATING UNIT



INTRODUCTION



In response to the requirements of Federal EPA, this Risk Management Plan has been developed for the Cliffside Steam Station (CSS) located in Cliffside, NC.  CSS is owned and operated by Duke Energy.  The RMP Resubmission includes administrative changes and PHA for a new process that will be supplying anhydrous ammonia to a new electric generating unit.   The new anhydrous ammonia process is similiar to the existing process on Unit 5.  They two systems will be operated independently.   



PLANT AND PROCESS INFORMATION



CSS uses anhydrous ammonia system as a component supporting selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of the plant's boiler emissions.  Ammonia vapor (in the presence of the SCR catalyst) reduces NOx compounds to elemental nitrogen and water to reduce the total NOx effluent emitted from the plant.  The first system was installed on Unit #5 in 2002. In 2012, a new coal burning electric generating plant (Unit 6) will go in production and use anhydrous ammonia to control NOx.  The new anhydrous ammonia system for Unit 6 is similiar to Unit 5.   The two systems will be operated independently. The anhydrous ammonia system is comprised of four storage tanks, two with a capacity of 45,000 gallons each, and two with capacity of 60,000 gallons each, along with feed pumps and vaporizing equipment.  The total quantity of ammonia exceeds threshold quantities which invoke the requirements of the Risk Management regulations.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION MEASURES



CSS is committed to public safety, employee safety, continued reliable operation, and regulatory compliance.  Based on this commitment, the Plant Manager has overall responsibility for the developmen

d will continue to handle ammonia in a smaller capacity system (below EPA threshold quantity) for flue gas conditioning.  The accident history for this existing use was reviewed for comparative purposes.  Within the past five years, CSS has had no accidental releases that resulted in injuries or property damage.  The plant has maintained an excellent safety record throughout its operating history and has never had any major chemical release that could have had adverse effects on the public.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE



In the event that an ammonia release does occur, CSS has an emergency response program that coordinates emergency response with the appropriate off-site agencies including the Rutherford and Cleveland County Emergency Planning and Management agencies and the Cliffside Fire Department.  CSS maintains a 24/7 emergency response team on-site with the appropriate number of members, training, and equipment to actively respond to and take action necessary to secure credible releases of ammonia that might occur.  Additionally, there are a number of emergency operations procedures in place which detail the appropriate emergency actions that would help mitigate the effects of releases.



MAINTAINING A SAFE OPERATION



Duke Energy and Cliffside Steam Station will continually work to safely manage the hazards of the ammonia system to protect the communities we serve and the employees, vendors and visitors at the station.  The Risk Management Program will be maintained to reduce the risk of accidental releases through training, procedures, equipment maintenance, and safe work practices.  Periodically, CSS will audit the program, review the Process Hazard Analysis, coordinate wth community emergency response organizations, and will update the program as needed to assure safe and efficient control and management of the anhydrous ammonia system.
